<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init_page_sizes:
```c
static int metal_init_page_sizes(void)
{
	const int max_sizes = MAX_PAGE_SIZES - 1;
	long sizes[max_sizes];

	/* Determine system page size. */
	sizes[0] = getpagesize();
	if (sizes[0] <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to get page size\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	_metal.page_size  = sizes[0];
	_metal.page_shift = metal_log2(sizes[0]);
	metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path, _metal.page_shift, 0);

#ifdef HAVE_HUGETLBFS_H
#ifndef MAP_HUGE_SHIFT
	/* System does not support multiple huge page sizes. */
	sizes[0] = gethugepagesize();
	if (sizes[0] > 0) {
		metal_add_page_size(hugetlbfs_find_path(),
				    metal_log2(sizes[0]),
				    MAP_HUGETLB);
	}
#else
	if (gethugepagesize() >= 0) {
		int i, count;

		/* System supports multiple huge page sizes. */
		count = gethugepagesizes(sizes, max_sizes);
		for (i = 0; i < count; i++) {
			int shift = metal_log2(sizes[i]);

			if ((shift & MAP_HUGE_MASK) != shift)
				continue;
			metal_add_page_size(
				hugetlbfs_find_path_for_size(sizes[i]),
				shift, (MAP_HUGETLB |
				(shift << MAP_HUGE_SHIFT)));
		}
	}
#endif
#endif

	/* Finally sort the resulting array by size. */
	qsort(_metal.page_sizes, _metal.num_page_sizes,
	      sizeof(struct metal_page_size), metal_pagesize_compare);

	return 0;
}
```

struct metal_page_size {
	/** Page size. */
	size_t	page_size;

	/** Page shift. */
	unsigned long page_shift;

	/** Path to hugetlbfs (or tmpfs) mount point. */
	char path[PATH_MAX];

	/** Flags to use for mmap. */
	int mmap_flags;
}
...
#define MAX_PAGE_SIZES 32
...
static int metal_add_page_size(const char *path, int shift, int mmap_flags)
{
	int index = _metal.num_page_sizes;
	unsigned long size = 1UL << shift;

	if (index >= MAX_PAGE_SIZES) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - overflow\n",
			  size);
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	}

	if (!path || shift <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - invalid args\n",
			  size);
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_shift = shift;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_size = size;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].mmap_flags = mmap_flags;
	strncpy(_metal.page_sizes[index].path, path, PATH_MAX);
	_metal.num_page_sizes++;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "added page size %ld @%s\n", size, path);

	return 0;
}
...
static int metal_pagesize_compare(const void *_a, const void *_b)
{
	const struct metal_page_size *a = _a, *b = _b;
	long diff = a->page_size - b->page_size;

	return metal_sign(diff);
}

explanation:
MISRA Rule 21.17 concerns use of <string.h> functions that can read/write beyond the bounds of objects. In the provided code the only direct call to a <string.h> function is the strncpy call inside metal_add_page_size, so that line should be investigated. Other fragments do not call string handling functions or otherwise do not present an obvious string.h-related out-of-bounds risk: 
- The gethugepagesizes(sizes, max_sizes) call passes the sizes array length (max_sizes) so the buffer size parameter is provided; the code uses the returned count to iterate and does not itself invoke any string.h routines. 
- Calls to metal_add_page_size (_metal.tmp_path, hugetlbfs_find_path(), hugetlbfs_find_path_for_size(...)) are callers that pass path pointers to metal_add_page_size; the only string.h activity occurs inside metal_add_page_size (the strncpy already listed). 
- qsort and metal_pagesize_compare do not use string handling functions. 
- metal_log and the macro expansion shown do formatting/logging but do not show any direct use of <string.h> functions in the provided snippets. 
Therefore no other code fragments need investigation under Rule 21.17 based on the supplied code.
